Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy, but it might not be. In many developed countries, rubbish collection is a common practice. Rubbish bags or bins are regularly collected by special trucks and taken to a landfill. Economists find this process strange because it is usually free. Households pay for it through local taxes, but a family that produces a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that produces little. However, disposing of rubbish is not free. More rubbish means more collectors and trucks are needed, and local authorities have to pay more for landfill fees. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The obvious solution is to charge households for the waste they produce. This would encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, assuming there are places to recycle. 
However, American economists Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman found that this approach can have unexpected and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging for rubbish. The most common system is selling stickers or tags for rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study of Charlottesville, Virginia, where residents were charged 80 cents per bag, the number of bags fell by 37%. But this was mainly because people packed more rubbish into each bag, a method known as the 'Seattle stomp'. The weight of rubbish collected, which is a better measure of disposal costs, only fell by 14%. In other Virginian cities without such a scheme, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also resorted to illegal dumping to avoid paying, which might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. 
One positive outcome was a 15% increase in recycling, as people chose to recycle for free rather than pay for rubbish collection. However, this might not be due to the fee, as many were already recycling voluntarily. In a later study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that pricing does reduce rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices only reduces rubbish by 0.3%. This is lower than other studies, but not surprising. To significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important. In wealthier towns, people throw out more rubbish and have less time to recycle. 
Should we abandon the idea of charging for rubbish? Not necessarily. Free disposal is too cheap, but simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand them, and the results are not always pleasant.

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Today, just being successful in your career isn't enough. Many professions feel undervalued, and even famous people often feel bitter. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to consider how your work affects you personally, including your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because no matter how skilled you are, if your job makes you boring or unable to talk to people outside your field, or if you're too busy to gain wisdom or use your imagination, then status or money won't make up for your lack as a person.
I am exploring how work can focus on fulfilling personal aspirations, rather than just shaping us for industrial needs. Work should not only create wealth but also offer a meaningful lifestyle, help discover hidden talents, and provide diverse human interactions. However, this doesn't mean eliminating unemployment is the only goal. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are enriching, interesting, and useful. A career should be like a work of art, with a fulfilled person at its center.
Even traditional middle-class jobs are losing their appeal. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, architects rarely use their creativity, and administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers, once proud of their status, are losing confidence. Companies and public institutions are downsizing, and strategies like decentralizing decisions and rewarding performance haven't gained employee commitment. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values match their organization's.
I am investigating various jobs to see how they shape or harm people. I've studied how different cultures expand human potential and create courage. Now, I'm focusing on finding more satisfying ways to earn a living. Many experts work on extending the life and income of companies, but we also need to evaluate ourselves as people and decide who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many are like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?
Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many intelligent and lively people endure low prestige, low pay, and long hours because hotels haven't been rethought since the days of the Ritz. A hotel is more than a place to sleep; it's like a mini United Nations where people from around the world meet but often don't interact. Many hotel staff are foreigners eager to learn new languages and cultures, but they have limited interaction with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests with the city and each other. Hoteliers could use the skills of the students they employ, rather than just giving them basic tasks. If they focused on their staff's ambitions, they would see many new services hotels could offer. But accountants often limit this by focusing on profit.
It's time to rethink what work means from a human perspective, not just a financial one. Work is a relationship. As people seek independence and personal expression at work, they should have the chance to design their jobs and choose their colleagues and customers, within practical and profitable limits. This requires communicating beyond professional jargon and engaging in meaningful conversations. True conversation is more than just communication; it's an intimate exchange that creates respect and can change participants. It's not just relaxing; it's a way to establish equality. Every meaningful conversation changes the world a little bit.

Broadcasting originally meant spreading seeds widely by hand, like in farming. This idea of broadcasting is not just about farming; it also represents the hope of modern times. It suggests planned growth and a rich outcome if conditions are right. The idea assumes there is a central source of seeds, or information, ready to be spread. The question is why a new technology that could send words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fit this farming metaphor.
Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a form of communication. But from the start, it was seen as a centralised 'mass' medium. Sending broadcasts from a central place to private homes matched the social and economic structures of modern societies. Other ways of organising television were tried but remained just experiments.
Two lesser-known alternatives show what television could have been in a different social setting. In the early 1930s, radio amateurs in Britain experimented with two-way television as a possible replacement for the telephone. Magazines like Radio News published articles on building TV transmitters and receivers. However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these grassroots efforts aside. This ended the chance for television to develop as a grassroots, equal form of communication in Britain.
Broadcasting was linked to strong economic interests and the deep structures of modern societies. In the USA in the early 1930s, television was mainly a medium for public viewing, often seen as a competitor to the film industry. In Britain and Germany, public viewing was how most people first experienced television. Although the idea of grassroots, two-way television was unlikely to succeed, public viewing systems in several countries in the 1930s posed a potential challenge to the home-based model of television. But this challenge did not last.
Manufacturers saw the potential for mass sales of home TV sets once prices dropped. With the division between public and private life in modern society, centralised broadcasting to homes was the most suitable way to organise television. As working-class people improved their living standards and joined consumer society from the 1920s, the dream of the home as a centre for entertainment became possible for many in Western countries. This trend is now happening globally.
There is a link between social modernisation and the main structures of broadcasting. As societies modernised, they became more centralised, with concentrated capital and political power. Traditional communities broke up, leading to new ways of life. People became more mobile, both socially and geographically, which left them more isolated than in stable early communities. Centralised broadcasting helped governments reach all citizens with important information and created a sense of national community.
Broadcasting became the dominant form of radio and television because of these structured processes and interests. However, broadcasting also played a positive role in democracy. Between the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way to ensure equal access to information needed for informed participation in political, social, and cultural life.
Television is changing, and the term broadcasting might become outdated. If that happens, the metaphor of broadcasting will be seen as describing a specific way of organising audio-visual technology during a certain phase of social modernisation.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things goes too far. Modern advertising is designed to make us feel insecure. It often suggests that if you don't have a certain product, you are not as good as others. To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads influence us in powerful ways without us even noticing. We see them everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, T-shirts, the internet—all telling us to buy more.
**Caves**  
Research centers and universities around the world have spent years studying caves, focusing on how they form, their water systems, and their living organisms. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, sparking our curiosity and desire to learn more. This has led to a lot of research. In places where caves have impacted human life, studies have been even more intense. However, exploring caves often requires physical skill, so cave research is not just done by professors. There is a unique overlap between professional scientists and amateur cave explorers who study caves for fun.
**Weather Watch**  
Many observant people, using only their senses, laid the groundwork for meteorology, which has become a highly technical science since the 17th century. Satellites and electronic tools now provide us with constant weather information quickly, and computers solve complex math problems faster than humans can. Meteorological theory uses many long words that can be confusing to non-experts. It might seem like there's no room for simple weather knowledge, but that's not true. Human experience is still crucial for turning computer data into weather forecasts. Human observations can offer unique insights that help professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**
Until recently, I believed opera was mainly about theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I realized that opera is primarily about music, with theatre coming second. This makes sense, but my background is in theatre, where the spoken word and the actor are most important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the performers and audience usually speak the same language.
At musical performances, whether in a concert hall or opera house, many people, like me, may not have a deep understanding of music. Some might feel embarrassed about what they don't know, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A brilliant singer or a perfect string section is easy to admire. Even a fairly good musician shows the results of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching an athletics match. We know athletes are doing something similar to what we do when running for a bus, but they do it much better.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't particularly impressed by something that seems close to what they could do themselves. They don't usually applaud when an actor finishes a long speech, although they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more generous or less demanding than music audiences. In fact, many people attend both. However, in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the play or spectacular the event.
The question is, should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes, because a different approach can change the concert-goer's experience. Live music is naturally theatrical, full of emotion, humor, sadness, intimacy, and grandeur. It can go wrong unexpectedly and engages the listener's imagination as part of a group. However, the formal traditions in music, like strict dress codes and high respect for conductors and soloists, highlight the difference between performers and listeners, which can feel hierarchical.
On the other hand, modern music audiences sometimes interrupt performances by clapping between movements or after a great solo. While this shows appreciation, it can disrupt the flow of the music. Can anything be done? Yes, a lot is being done. There are efforts to attract new audiences to concert halls and opera houses and to make 'serious' music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a top-quality musical experience, and it was life-changing for many in the audience, who also participated.
What I hope for in music is more of the risk and boldness that theatre can show. This can come from using unusual or challenging locations, which change normal expectations. This can have surprising effects on both performers and audiences. Comforts might be sacrificed, the sound might not be perfect, or it might be a bit cold, but theatre audiences have learned to be adventurous and follow artists into unexpected spaces. I know most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe something should change in music conventions. My only authority is as an enthusiast: I love theatre and spend as much time and money as I can on music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**  
While I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I don't really like it in its natural form. To me, sand is mostly an annoying obstacle between the car park at the beach and the water. It blows into your face, gets into your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you're wet, sand sticks to you like glue and is hard to remove, even with a strong water spray. But strangely, as soon as you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, sand falls off you. For days, you keep finding sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more sand flies around when you take off your socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. No, I don't like sand at all.
**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home for privacy and security since they first started building houses. The simple wooden bar behind the door has been replaced by electronic locks that use a plastic card with countless combinations. But the desire to keep out intruders is still the same. Locks and keys are partly about feeling secure. Recently, some companies have tried using computerized locks, where smart cards control electronic locks. But people don't really like them. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone prefers the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when a locksmith company created a new electronic system, they made sure to include a real metal key in it.
**Modern Art**  
I was worried about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I don't really understand modern art. I know I like some of it, especially things with fur, neon light sculptures, and large photos. Maybe if I knew more about it, I'd have opinions on more pieces. But you're not supposed to analyze it like a school essay. The idea is to let art speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the art. The first thing I noticed were the labels, real labels that explain the context of the art and what it's trying to say. Instead of just staring at the pictures without understanding, these bits of information helped me get it.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
When adapting novels into films, a lot of the original content is often reduced or removed. This can be frustrating for writers but also enlightening. While working on a script, I realized that much of the dialogue and description in a novel can be cut without losing the main point. This doesn't mean the original content was unnecessary. It's about how each medium—books and films—engages the audience differently and uses repetition in its own way. In novels, repetition helps readers remember character traits and who is speaking. In stage plays, dialogue often mimics real speech, sometimes using a lot of unnecessary words just to keep the conversation going, which can make it hard to understand what's really being communicated.
**Watching Movies**
Watching movies can be an immersive experience, making you feel part of the film's world. During the movie, you escape from reality, but once the film ends, you're back to the real world. In the past, movies were seen as just entertainment, not art. Many people, including our parents and teachers, thought movies were not serious art, even though they enjoyed watching them.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios were a confusing mix of different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were many similar rooms and no clear main entrance. There were three entrances, but only one led to where you wanted to go. Visitors were rare because the studio didn't encourage them, but employees knew their way around. Together, they created films that offered audiences a break from everyday life, providing romance and adventure.
**Film-makers**
Many people dream of making movies. Bookstores are full of guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer courses. Competitions offer cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his low-budget film El Mariachi, which launched his career. Rodriguez achieved his dream early, making his breakthrough film by age 23. In the past, filmmakers took longer to succeed. They gained experience working in different roles before directing. John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, and Fred Zinnemann found success in his forties. Today, without studio support, aspiring filmmakers often have to be independent and resourceful.

In those days, council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of cramped, dull homes made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, filled the air with a strong sulfur smell. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked up to someone's front door. 
Most of my early life is a blur, but I remember sitting, or maybe balancing, near an upstairs window, watching the houses fade into the distance. Later, I have vague memories of faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling over the turrets of a mansion at Earlham. My mother often appears in these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I sensed that her personality was unusual. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a crowded room as she was on a moor. 
She also had a strict sense of propriety, which was rare on the West Earlham estate. This sometimes led to intense cleaning or handwashing and instructions to 'behave properly.' As a moral code, it was beyond my understanding, and even now, I'm not sure I get it. It meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly in the dining room with your hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and many other rules and restrictions.
Over time, other people appeared in these strict early scenes. Despite her solitude, my mother had friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who was obsessed with the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier and somewhat disapproved of by the others. Later, I realized that this group was not great company. They were a sad and depressing group, talking about bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children, a category I often felt I belonged to. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight made up of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders, and I needed to grow up and free myself from it. This was easier said than done.
Growing up in West Earlham at that time followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home, often getting in your parents' way. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug in the front room while my mother sat coldly in an armchair. Then, the September after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile away towards the city. The lucky few had a mother with a rickety bike and a child seat. As far as I remember, my mother let other children in the street take care of me on this journey.
If I remember anything about those early years, it's the summer holidays, when you got glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy, and a charity fete once at a house far away on Christchurch Road, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to interest me in something called the League of Pity, a kind of junior charity. But my mother dismissed it, saying the organizers were 'only after your money.' My mother often talked about people having selfish motives, and she had a deep contempt for politicians. If she thought about the House of Commons, it was as a place where rich people opened letters full of money sent by a gullible public. I might be exaggerating, and I might overlook her good qualities and focus on her flaws. But my mother didn't have much kindness; it seemed to have been taken from her.
To be fair, my mother did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she would take me, dressed in my 'good clothes,' on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. There, we would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother wasn't completely against this activity and eventually almost had opinions on the art. I remember her stopping once in front of a painting of a Roman soldier in full battle gear and saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' I recall this as the only time my mother tried to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down the odd-numbered side of Philadelphia Avenue. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick and humid, turning into a light, prickly rain. This made my walk feel secretive and sheltered. I knew this side of the street well since I was a child. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends, all girls, lived in the houses of the Krings and the Pottses. Even though I didn't know everyone by name, each house was unique to me, just like the small channels in the cement that guided rain from the roofs to the street. These channels were important landmarks when I was on my roller skates or scooter. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed to get smaller and the front yards became tiny. Over the years, things changed: wooden porch railings and pillars were replaced with wrought iron, giving a Southern or Spanish look. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, turned back into homes. I wondered how people lived in these spaces that used to be shops, with the lingering smells of merchandise.
**Bachelor Fads**
Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and large doors, which were used to bring in curtains from trains on the nearby railway. However, Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space because it was hard to separate work from home life. In his previous place, the living and working areas were combined, making it difficult to relax or focus on work. So, he divided the space near the entrance with a large sheet of corrugated plastic. This screen hides the office, creates a hallway, and directs attention to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. Gilbert wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area where he could either cook for friends or make coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic screen and stainless steel kitchen, he used light wood for the floors. His flat is filled with futuristic chairs and sofas, but also with sentimental furniture from his parents or bought from markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and mysteries, making his adventurous lifestyle a topic of literary debate. Despite this, he was a brilliant and unique writer. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It combined the excitement of a thriller, the charm of romantic fiction, and deep insights. Chatwin often mixed fact with fiction, changing details to make stories more interesting. His book suggested that through travel, one could discover entire histories that seemed to exist just to captivate future explorers.
**Swimming**
During a warm summer rain in 1996, I hurried across my lawn and took shelter in the pool. As I swam, I watched raindrops create small fountains that turned into bubbles and burst. The best moments were when the storm got stronger, silencing the birds, and a mist rose from the water as if the pool was reaching up to the sky. It was then that I thought about a long swim through Britain. I wanted to follow the rain's path to the sea, breaking free from the routine of swimming laps. In our world, many places and things are clearly marked and explained, which can make reality feel like just a visual experience. Activities like walking, cycling, and swimming help us reconnect with the wild and mysterious parts of the world by going off the beaten path. A swimming journey would let me explore parts of the world that, like darkness, misty woods, or high mountains, still hold mystery.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying had no clear purpose in evolution. He was probably wrong. More recent scientists have shown its social importance. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps create a bond between mother and child. Many think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than the visual signal it sends. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing injustice. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, like when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We might cry during a sentimental movie, but this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying seems clear, but research is still ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect us? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but its exact consequences are unclear. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, any climate changes will significantly impact plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans have used these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support six billion people. Any changes to these resources are serious.
The challenge is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. Over the last 100 years, human activities have increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperatures. These gases are likely affecting the global climate, but our limited understanding of the Earth's heat balance makes the future uncertain. We know that greenhouse gas levels have changed along with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not natural and is partly due to human pollution.
A lot of research uses computer models called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict future climate conditions. These models use physics and chemistry to analyze temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other factors. However, they simplify the real world and have limitations. Their predictions are only estimates, and they are costly and slow to run. We do not fully understand all climate processes, but we know they are complex.
Despite these challenges, most agree that the rate of climate change will be faster than anything we've seen before. GCMs help us understand what the world might be like in the future. They predict that by 2100, the average global temperature could rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels could rise by 15-95 cm, and precipitation patterns could change. Extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, may become more common in some areas. These forecasts show the potential impact of climate change on nature and humans.
Climate changes could affect where ecosystems like forests and grasslands are located, the species they contain, and their ability to provide benefits that societies rely on. This includes food production, water resources, and human settlements. Some effects might be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some impacts could be beneficial. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields since 1952 due to fewer frosts.
However, many predicted effects of future warming are not beneficial. Small climate changes can affect water availability, either by long-term drying or more frequent droughts. Problems are likely to start in dry regions and areas with existing water shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where rainfall patterns have changed, with more rain in autumn and winter and less in spring.
Another concern is changes to glaciers, which will affect ice and, in turn, vegetation, wildlife, and human structures. The Arctic ice might melt completely, making marine transport and oil exploration easier but increasing iceberg risks. The most dramatic effect of global warming could be rising sea levels due to ocean expansion and melting ice. With about half the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could cause severe flooding. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could face significant disruptions, and many people might lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island nations could be most affected, as they might disappear entirely, causing devastating impacts on their people and culture, and creating challenges for countries that would need to accommodate displaced populations.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This is the type of people needed for the first mission to Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a spacecraft on 5 January 2018 succeed. The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next chance to launch, when Mars and Earth are in the right positions, won't be until 2031. It's a big challenge, and the race is on to create systems with completely new technologies. If these can be developed quickly enough, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it never launches, the work to reach these ambitious goals will still be valuable, as it will help future missions.'

**Aesthetics**
Sometimes, the very existence of art can make it hard to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art is often seen as just physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the true essence of art is what it does to our experiences. This misunderstanding can hinder our understanding of art.
Moreover, when art becomes highly admired and gains a classic status, it can become disconnected from the human experiences and conditions that created it. This separation makes it difficult to grasp the broader significance of art, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often placed in a separate realm, away from other human efforts and achievements.
A key task for anyone studying the philosophy of fine arts is to reconnect art with everyday life experiences. Just like mountain peaks are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. Geographers and geologists explain how mountains are connected to the earth, and similarly, art theorists should show how art is connected to human life.
To truly understand art, we need to temporarily set aside the art objects themselves and focus on the everyday experiences that we don't usually consider as aesthetic. This means taking a detour to understand art. Just like one can enjoy flowers without knowing plant biology, understanding art requires looking at the basic experiences that capture our attention and bring us joy.
Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips without considering them as art. This is because art is often seen as something that belongs in museums and galleries. However, the desire for enjoyable experiences finds its way into everyday life. Even those who criticize the museum view of art often still separate art from ordinary experiences.
The best times for appreciating art are when it is closely connected to everyday life and work. This connection makes appreciation more widespread and intense.

**Observing Lions**
People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team: in the evening light, a group of silent cats jumps from the shadows like skilled hunters and surrounds their prey. Lions seem like the perfect social animals, putting aside small disagreements to work together for a common goal - their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise cubs, and scare off rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its offspring survive, then working together might not always be beneficial: if an animal is too generous, others might benefit at its expense. So, why don't the evolutionary rules of self-interest apply to lions? We thought we could answer this question in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, lions are inactive. It has taken many research methods to find clues about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand the answers to our questions.
**Pop Music Review**
The release of Bedrock's third album was a major event for the band, which had been talented but unstable. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. The serious and plain style of the past, with loud guitars, was replaced by a lighter mix of melodic local styles. The album combined social observation and strong emotions with the sounds of fairground organs and northern brass bands. Humor and irony were prominent, as were voices that didn't hide their origins. The album showed Bedrock as skilled collectors and observers, and a clever team of songwriters. They explored traditional English themes like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its gentle, sad songs like 'So Low', a beautiful tune about weather, and 'To the Brink', a serious ballad. The beauty of "New Life" is its consistently high quality - 16 tracks with no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I was always interested in stories about 'The Sibyl', wise women who had great influence in ancient times. At first, I only knew about one from a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered Tarquin, King of Rome, nine books for 300 gold pieces. He refused, and she burned three books, then offered him six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He bought the last three for the full price. I realized there was a deep truth in the story - a lesson in salesmanship and life. I was sometimes a lonely only child. I would ask to play with other children and be refused. My mother told me to do something so interesting that other kids would want to join me. It worked, and it was a lesson I never forgot. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I wanted to learn about, something relevant to my life. I'm not a keen traveler - I sent my editor a long list of places I didn't want to go. I'm only interested in ruins because I like traveling through time in my mind.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you submit your manuscript, it will likely join a pile waiting to be sorted - the so-called slush pile. This is usually done by a junior in the editorial department (under 18) or an experienced person who works part-time. Neither has much influence, but they want to find something original - the junior to make a name and find an author, the experienced person to keep their freelance job. If they think your novel is promising, they will pass it to a senior editor, and it will eventually be discussed at an acquisition meeting. The editor will need to justify accepting your novel based on its quality and potential sales, and also consider if you seem like a long-term prospect (which you will have assured them in your letter). They will also consider how promotable you are, which is important when a new novel needs support. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**
If you worked in an advertising agency in the early 1990s, it might have been the hardest time in your career. The recession was severe, lasting longer and hitting harder than expected, especially in industrialized countries. In Britain, 1991 was tough: the GDP went down, interest rates stayed high, people spent less on everything except essentials, over half a million people lost their jobs, and about 75,000 homes were repossessed. Every business felt the impact, with some industries like vehicles and construction seeing a 30% drop. Many people and companies in different countries suffered.
Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept theirs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help improve company profits and were closely watched by their colleagues and bosses. They also had to do more with less money, being told that "less must be more." Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing grew. Companies started focusing more on creating products and services that customers actually wanted, rather than just what was easy for them to produce. This shift meant marketing got more attention from management, and some brands began to be marketed effectively. This increased the status of marketing professionals but also added to their responsibilities. Marketing was seen as a solution to all problems, which it is not.
About half of most marketing budgets go to advertising, so advertising professionals felt the pressure. The 1980s were great for advertising, but the early 1990s were tough. This was partly due to the economy, but also because clients started questioning the value of advertising. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money. Without clear evidence of advertising's benefits, many clients doubted its value. They wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, media placement, and thinking from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard to produce outstanding work.
Advertising professionals faced the same problem as their clients: doing more with less. The recession made it hard to produce effective advertising. Production costs were controversial, and there was a reluctance to take risks, which are often key to good advertising. Other challenges included demographic changes, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, stricter legal restrictions, and the challenge of advertising abroad.
These issues forced advertisers to reconsider the saying: "Only half my advertising works. The trouble is I don't know which half." Now, more than ever, there is pressure to make sure more advertising is effective. However, help for improving advertising is not easy to find. Companies and agencies are busy dealing with these challenges and are reluctant to share their successful strategies. Conferences and seminars might offer some help, but books on advertising often don't. They tend to overestimate the quality and value of advertising work, which doesn't help those responsible for it.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was at university, I decided I wanted to become a chef. This was not a common choice among my peers. Cooking wasn't considered a desirable job. On the surface, being a chef seems unattractive. Chefs are known for having tough lives: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. But these factors didn't discourage me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were difficult, and the social life felt closed-off and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect escape from this. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life. However, my desire to cook wasn't just a reaction to being a student. It also represented an artistic ideal for me. I first saw this ideal when I ate at a famous London restaurant. It was eye-opening. I still remember my starter clearly. After that meal, I felt like I wanted to thank the chef deeply. I felt happy and light for days. After this experience, I wanted to learn the secrets of this amazing art. I turned my student life into a preparation for entering the culinary world. My history degree felt empty, distracting me from my real passion. I learned about cooking in a random and incomplete way by reading cookbooks, visiting markets and delicatessens, and making elaborate meals.
**The Swimming Instructor**
The school's swimming instructor was a former drill sergeant, small and muscular, with tattooed arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this move until the lesson was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with disapproval: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight." "Point your toes, I said!" The following week, I went up onto the high diving board. It was a fixed board, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Gradually, the echoing voices faded, and I felt like I was in silence. I moved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, not down, and jumped into the air. For a brief moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs went everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disdain and shook his head. But even he couldn't take away my happiness. "That's what they mean by 'free as a bird'," I thought.
**The Traveller**
For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the likelihood of living at least until tomorrow, the idea of the traveller is both confusing and fascinating. These are people who are drawn to the unknown, who choose to risk their lives by climbing steep, icy mountains prone to avalanches; who sail alone in small boats through huge waves; who will eat maggots and river insects if there's nothing better to eat, and who can live for months in the uncertainty of the unknown. It's easy to see these people as odd - and they are - like hermits, freefall divers, or writers. They exist, but their strange, uncomfortable world is far from our everyday experience and can be dismissed as irrelevant. We can ignore them and return to our world of microwaves and answering machines, grateful that the only risks we face are predictable ones, like running across a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, saying it is not his natural environment, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He doesn't claim to be a top sailor, though he is clearly a capable one. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about his sailing experiences. Sailing provides plenty of challenges and successes for him to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that tells sailors their exact position anywhere on Earth. While he appreciates this tool, Raban has a somewhat old-fashioned view of other sailing aids. He believes the invention of the compass was a mistake, causing a "fundamental break in the relationship between man and sea." Raban argues that since the compass was invented, about a thousand years ago, it has become the main focus for sailors, so they no longer need to study the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, once full of activity, is now just a space. Since the sailor's job is just to stay on course, an autopilot can replace them for long periods. This might be why Raban had time to observe the waves so closely.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely linked. Books help us feel more connected to the world. We can relate our experiences to those in books from long ago or faraway places because there are fewer types of people than there are people. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought we were alone in feeling, or express our thoughts with clarity we can't achieve. What is unclear in us is clearly expressed in their words, especially if the book is from a different place or time. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves. Through reading and travel, we break free from routine. Our eyes are most open in a new place, or when reading a great book, which shows us things we ignored before. Our mind becomes aware of new details, like the sky's colors, a friend's behavior, or a hidden sadness we didn't know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel reflections were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have restored some small cuts made by the editor to fit the page, but added very little. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were important details. I could have made more changes, but that would never end. For example, in an article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed the article to predict this, it would not be a true report from that time. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, not knowing what would happen next, and trying to understand what had already happened. This is the real story of mass travel: the world opening up to people who only need a ticket. But I believe my fellow travelers are not blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for overused tourism phrases, 'ecotourism' would win. The term appeared in the early 1980s, when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized travelers wanted to believe their trips wouldn't harm the environment. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, 'ecotourism' includes anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour involving culture, nature, wildlife, or adventure is labeled ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but without clear rules, many travelers are confused by the term.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it by luck a few years ago. It helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn't perfect. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, staying in welcoming country houses for weeks. When I stopped traveling, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again, and sometimes only made short notes instead of full stories. Worried that details might be out of order, I added many warnings in my writing. But then I realized this wasn't a guidebook, so I let the story flow without too many explanations.

**Fashion**
Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, linked to the capitalism of the 19th and 20th centuries. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the market and trade growth in the 16th and 17th centuries. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new technologies for making different types of clothing and accessories have been discovered, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems very uniform, can have different meanings in different situations and to different people.
**Writer**
Newspaper stories about publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us not at the top of the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't become a hit. Others, like me, do various literary jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten anything like that. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs, using credit cards, and often with help from the people mentioned in Acknowledgements, the novel gets written.
**Sudden Fame**
The small venues we were playing at around the country were starting to sell out, and extra security was needed to control the growing number of screaming fans. We had to use secret entrances to the places we performed to avoid being mobbed. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, this was replaced by a strange confidence that only shy people in similar situations can understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Challenges**
Technology keeps changing how we live, work, and enjoy our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. It's clear that more people will have access to music because it meets many human needs. Music is part of every major state event and offers many activities for individuals. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.
I believe people will continue to learn instruments. The music industry is a big source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for jobs, especially in media. Besides job opportunities, playing an instrument can help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. Although these findings need more support, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social relationships in schools and help children focus, especially those with behavioral issues. Further research is looking into whether playing an instrument can help develop skills that can be used in other areas. For example, regular practice can lead to good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of these benefits, there will likely be a demand for music lessons in the near future.
Looking further ahead, will there be changes in focus, and if so, what will they be? I think two things might happen. First, people will listen to a wider variety of music, with new genres mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more in composing and performing music, making it easier for people to create music without needing as much technical skill. However, this might also mean fewer live performances and less need for musicians who only perform live. At the same time, more people of all ages might want to make music themselves, often in community settings that reflect local musical traditions.
To prepare for this future, the music profession needs to change. Instrumental teaching should adapt to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will affect the music curriculum and how progress is measured, requiring changes to stay relevant for more people. Music education will need to cover a wider range of skills. Musicians will need to inspire and teach people of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and develop communication, social, entrepreneurial, and management skills for community work. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability to the public. Positively, this is a chance for music educators to show the quality of music teaching available.
Finally, we need to raise the importance of music. Music is vital in our lives but is often overlooked. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Actors sometimes face criticism and disrespect. This often happens when they talk about their work in interviews, which can lead to clichés or gossip. They could learn from dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it," when asked to explain her dance. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote that acting only has life when performed. Discussing it makes it seem empty and theoretical. Acting has no strict rules, except maybe being heard clearly. With each new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the characters and the writer's insights. After a play ends, actors feel empty until the next project. This emptiness is noticeable when discussing theatre work.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet is a mix of youth and maturity, showing simplicity and confidence. His control over the text and his physical presence make him a standout actor. Lester plays a tense young man with hidden anger, using sharp wit and humor that make him both intimidating and likable. His performance is subtle yet clearly skilled. Watch how his body seems ready to come alive. Similarly, Handy's portrayal of Horatio shows a body moved by an inner force. This raises questions about acting and behavior: Is acting an imitation or a true expression? What drives these performances, both morally and physically? This is a key question in theatre.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager projects the script on a screen. Actors sit quietly, absorbing the words. When it's their turn, they look at the screen, understand the phrase, and wait for the impulse to speak. For example, with the line "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, let the thought sink in, and visualize the scene. They find the reason to speak, which the director calls "The pathway to the line." Impulses can come from outside or within. Actors should look into each other's eyes and consider their character's situation. The director encourages not to plan too much but to trust that something will happen naturally.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theatre should make you feel like your presence matters. Going to a live performance is an event, and the staff should recognize that. It's off-putting if the staff seems indifferent. The theatre should create a connection between the performer and the audience. Everyone should feel they have a fair view of the actor, not too far away, and able to hear and see clearly. The size of the auditorium is important; it should suit the human voice and body. If the space is too large, it loses the human touch essential to drama. Many theatres from the late 19th century got this right, creating spaces that embrace the stage. Theatres with a sense of history, like worn steps in a church, give a feeling of past human presence. You can't please everyone with a play, and audiences often don't know what they want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to experience something unexpected, something you couldn't imagine at home.

**Paul Simon**
In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular among young people, but its real importance was how it changed the lives of middle-class and older people. It also set the stage for future rock stars, who listened to it and felt that this new, exciting music would be a big part of their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this fresh and exciting music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was a must-listen for many young people who wanted to become rock stars. Just like young John Lennon, who was far away in Liverpool listening to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon was captivated by the music from Freed's show. He was getting ready to move from just listening to music to creating his own.
**Snow**
There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me down as I slipped on the icy ground. Suddenly, the snow, which looked harmless, collapsed under me. I fell, surprised, into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had made a cover over a gap between two rocks, and it melted away, leaving only a thin layer that I broke through. I pulled myself out, feeling shaken and worried, thinking about what I would have done if the hole had been much deeper. I sat against the top of a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In an hour, I had only traveled about half a mile. It was clear that I needed to change my plan.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books now that try to help researchers with qualitative research. While a lot has been written about collecting data, these books often don't explain much about how to analyze the data. There is a lot of mystery around how researchers look at their data. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about the methods they used. The goal was to share insights and understanding of the process of analyzing qualitative data, not to create a guidebook for new researchers. This means making hidden methods more clear. While this might seem easy, we found it quite challenging. We allowed our contributors to present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal approaches.

**Screen Learning**
Recently, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a strange way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur," acting out a scene from a TV show he watched. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't recall much. Many people are eager to use the internet and computers for learning, but is learning from a screen effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned more. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that suggests ideas rather than teaches them directly. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is dialogue with teachers or parents. It needs guidance. While new technology can be useful for teaching, formal education still plays a crucial role.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. Local people didn't like it, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by these newcomers. However, they eventually accepted it because of the success it brought. In Hollywood, success is measured by how much money a film makes. A good film might make someone a star, but it must make money. In less than a century, Hollywood grew from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot; a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it is still like a village, with a narrow focus on films. People there talk about how much money films make, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to leave, working there but living elsewhere. Still, Hollywood is the place where almost everyone in show business eventually goes.
**Photography**
Photography was created by 19th-century artists as a new art form. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it in photography. The combination of light, lenses, shutters, and chemicals on a flat surface created images that were more lasting and detailed than paintings. This worried other artists, and after their initial excitement, art critics argued that photography wasn't true art. They believed that because photography relied on mechanical means, it couldn't be considered a product of human creativity. Despite this criticism, photographers knew they had discovered a new form of art. They used photography to interpret the world and show their vision of nature and people, just like artists use brushes and pencils.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, it was common for every children's book to have illustrations, even novels for older readers. However, as the number of printed books decreased, this practice declined. Children's publishing was active but often operated on a low budget, leading to some routine and mediocre work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white illustrations from this time are a mix of ordinary and exceptional work, offering a rich area for research and discovery. The best works are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reissues of books or exhibitions of original illustrations. There are signs that interest in this period is returning, and publishers may soon see the potential for reprinting classic children's book illustrations or creating new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
Some time ago, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins—telling everyone online where you are. The message was clear: you might think you're just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also letting everyone know you're not at home, which might not be safe. This highlighted the risks of sharing too much online. The internet offers many chances to share our lives with a global audience, promising things like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing confessions, photos, and stories. But soon, we realize it's a crowded and risky place, and we can get lost. 
Feeling down? Maybe, but don't lose hope. There's a guide to this future, created by early internet users. In the early days of the web, these pioneers explored the online world and faced its dangers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the challenges of fame, all before social media existed. These early bloggers have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, we should learn from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.
In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting online. Back then, the web was mostly used by students, scientists, and a few curious teenagers like him. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were drawn to his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might end up on his site, and no topic was off-limits. While some saw him as an exhibitionist, others recognized the art in his work.
One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video titled "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen deeply in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was given an ultimatum: "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the issue remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you expect it to make people like you, you'll be disappointed.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague anonymously sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including those she had criticized. This led to her losing her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect": the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes.
Armstrong's story ended well. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her family. Today, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once an example of online mistakes, she has become skilled at sharing her life carefully. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because the web lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

Title: Are We Getting Enough Sleep?
Tiredness is often said to be a common problem in modern life. As countries become richer and busier, more people seem to struggle with sleeplessness and anxiety. In the USA, research shows that 40 million Americans suffer from chronic sleep issues. In Britain, some popular novels feature characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep, its patterns, its benefits, and the problems related to it. A key concern is that people need more sleep. A leading sleep researcher says, "People cut back on sleep when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic."
A sleep researcher conducted an experiment where he let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle into sleeping about eight-and-a-quarter hours a night, showing they needed to catch up on lost sleep.
In Europe, a university sleep research lab in the English Midlands studies sleep issues. They have looked into how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise impacts sleep, and the risks of driving when tired. They recruit volunteers through student newspapers, pay them £5 an hour, and ask them to change their sleep patterns for the study. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures participants who worry about electrodes on their heads, explaining that the lab is more interested in physical responses.
In a dark room, there is a motorway simulator with a car facing a large screen. Participants arrive at 2 pm, during the body's natural afternoon slump, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road seems endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Many deny they will fall asleep, but Dr. Reyner has a video of one person trying not to. At first, he sits upright, eyes fixed on the road. Then he starts blinking more often, his head nodding. Each nod gets heavier, and the blinks turn into 10-second blackouts. He wakes up suddenly, but by then, the car has veered off the road. A coffee might help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for over half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests using alertness products like tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers.
What do we know for sure about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, they go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain keeps the body still to prevent injuries. Beyond this, there are theories. Some say sleep repairs the body, restores muscles, or rests the brain's creative parts. But these might also happen when we're awake but relaxed, so it's not certain. Scientists are sure that women sleep about half an hour longer than men and that older people need less sleep, though they don't know why.
When asked about the purpose of sleep, some researchers say, "Sleep is a way to pass time safely." Sleep patterns may have been different in the past. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people had different sleep routines. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight for an hour, and then had a "morning sleep." This break was a time for reflection, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest benefited most from this quiet time, free from daily work. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping in one long stretch, which was more efficient. The industrial revolution later made most people work longer hours in lit buildings, changing sleep patterns further.
Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western cultures, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. Continuous sleep is not the norm. In some tribal societies, noise, fire-watching, and predator threats make uninterrupted sleep impossible. It seems that people worldwide need more sleep.

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, each costing 800 dollars, while standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had the full cowboy outfit, but I didn't feel like a real cowboy. As I looked at the Arizona mountains in the morning sun, I realized I didn't belong there. I had flown in from Denver and briefly felt like a cowboy, but that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a dirty bag. He noticed my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without a word.
I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. It was my passion and all I knew how to do. But now, I can't race anymore. I wondered what I should do next. A racing driver should have other plans for when they stop racing, but mine seemed to vanish. I thought about becoming a commentator for races, but there were already many former drivers doing that. I also tried to start a business selling classic cars, but it didn't work out because nobody was buying them.
Being an "ex" anything is tough. People don't want to hear stories about almost being a champion. Even if I had been a champion, people would only listen for a short time. I don't want sympathy because I had a good career and made money. But I miss the thrill of racing, the fast cars, and the excitement. I miss being famous, even a little bit. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me, and kids wanted my autograph.
Now that I don't race, my phone hardly rings. I have a lot of free time. I looked at the sky and noticed there were no buzzards, just some small birds in a cactus nearby. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn about life outside of racing, just like a fake cowboy in fancy boots.

**Vancouver**
In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, located in western Canada. In the evenings, locals like to walk around the city, and if you join them, you'll probably hear many different languages. People are attracted to Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and opportunities for education and work. Although some people complain about the rapid construction of new buildings, it's clear that new residents and a growing tourism industry have contributed to the city's revival. Vancouver used to be called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Even though this name is not used as much now, Vancouver is still very much a gateway city.
**Putting Pen to Paper**
Journalists, like me, are often not very good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think we're that focused on money. It's more likely because, in our work, we always try to make a big impact, so the natural flow of a letter is lost on us. Real creative artists, who don't consciously think about the impact of their words (even if they rewrite a passage many times), don't have this issue. I think the true test of a real artist is their natural understanding of the effect of their words. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't consciously think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed his talent as a great writer.
**Supermarket Opening**
In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. You could expect a soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, waiting pensioners didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer, who knew someone working there, said the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly among the crowd, making those at the front feel pleased and those who arrived late feel envious.

**Citizen Kane**
When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, it faced a lot of controversy. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about the reaction of William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the subject of the film. Despite receiving mostly excellent reviews, the film was not a commercial hit at first. It was television that later made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most influential film, inspiring many people to become filmmakers. This is even more impressive because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film's success came from not knowing what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper owner who was similar to Hearst, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor. He took the opportunity with great enthusiasm.
**Dermot and Carmel**
Dermot noticed that Carmel seemed a bit strange that morning. He mentioned twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and the golf club was the best place for it. Carmel nodded her head in agreement, but it seemed like she wasn't really listening. "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I might walk downtown and look at the shops. It feels almost wrong to just spend the day doing nothing." Dermot smiled back and said, "You deserve to enjoy yourself. And as I mentioned, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't worry about it." "No, that's fine," she replied.
**Title Race**
Human nature can be quite amusing. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of jealousy and tension at work. A survey by a top recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that job titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more impressive job title over a pay raise. If our desire for status is so strong that it even surpasses our basic desire for more money, we are in a difficult situation. In today's world, no one wants to be seen as less important. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways of saying the same thing.

I was in Vienna to take photos. That was usually why I traveled anywhere. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light could change a scene and how one photo could capture the essence of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, as long as I had film in my camera. I would finish one roll, load another, and keep looking for that perfect shot. This was my way of life for a long time.
I once took a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well that became very popular. Newspapers and magazines around the world wanted it. It was a brief moment of success, mostly due to luck. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer. It seemed like a smart move, but life didn't go as planned. The mid-1990s weren't as successful as I had hoped, even though my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad.
The Vienna assignment came by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The publishers liked my work, and when the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the project, they asked me to take his place.
